Problem:
Consider a linear system described by the complex function \\(z(t) = Ce^{i \\omega t}z_0\\), where C is a complex constant, \\(\\omega\\) is the angular frequency, and \\(z_0\\) is the initial complex state. We investigate the consequences of an integral transformation on this system, denoted by \\(T_{\\lambda}[z](t) = \\int_0^t e^{-\\lambda (t-\\tau)} z(\\tau) d\\tau\\), where \\(\\lambda\\) is a decay factor.

If during the system’s evolution at time \\(t_1\\), we apply another transformation \\(T_{\\mu}[z](t)\\) (where \\(\\mu\\) is another decay constant), will the final state \\(z(T)\\) for T > t_1 depend solely on \\(C\\) and \\(\\omega\\) and not any of the transformations ((\\(\\lambda\\) or \\(\\mu\\))?
Explanation: Introducing the second decay factor \\(\\mu\\) at a specific time modifies the trajectory by applying a different weighting to the integral. Thus, the resultant state \\(z(T)\\) depends on the complex interactions of both decay factors along with the original dynamics imposed by \\(C\\) and \\(\\omega\\).
